text: Fractures the input geometry based on a material type.
This node allows you to accurately fracture geometry based on a specific type of material. Currently concrete, glass panels, and wood are supported.

It accepts four inputs: geometry, constraint geometry, proxy geometry, and an optional input for extra points to control the fracturing process. It will fracture the incoming geometry using different fracturing method depending on the material specified in the
parameter. If an input constraint geometry is specified, it will update the constraints for the fractured pieces.
for a guide to fracturing workflows and tools in Houdini.
node will allow you to switch between different displays. All materials have
, which will display the group being fractured.
, which will display the internal constraint network of all fractured pieces.
. These views allow you to display the volume distribution for each primary fracture level used for scattering and display the boolean cutting planes used to generate the edge detail.
There are also two glass-specific displays:
. These views allow you to display the noise used for determining the discontinuity for concentric cracks and display the magnitude distribution of the edge noise.
The three wood-specific displays allow you to display the cutting planes for grains, cuts, and splinters.
. These views allow you to display the volume distribution for the built-in scattered cutter geometry, display the cutter geometry, and the cutter geometry with the edge detail noise.
The geometry to be fractured. If no group is specified, the full input geometry will be fractured.
The type of material of the incoming geometry.
Glass material type. Only flat glass panel is currently supported.
Adds a namespace prefix to the name of each piece. This is useful for avoiding duplicated piece names or isolating a group of constraints.

Loop through each piece in the input geometry and fracture them individually.
    If the
is not found, it will fracture based on connectivity.
The primitive attribute that defines each piece for partitioning.

Fractures a specific piece at the given index.
    This can be useful for debugging and testing using a single piece.
Seed used when adding random variation of the parameters for each piece.
The prefix applied to the name of each piece created by the fracture.

Reset the currently cached display in the for loop.
    Use this to update the guide geometry if it is not displaying the current geometry.
The group that is currently being fractured will be highlighted.
Display the volume distribution for each primary fracture level used for scattering.
Display the cutting planes used to generate the edge detail.
Display the constraint network of all pieces.
Turning this off will bypass this fracture level.
The number of levels of recursive fracturing to perform.
The fracture ID for this fracture level. The output attributes and groups associated with this fracture level will have this tag.
The ratio out of all the pieces from the previous level to fracture at this level.
The random seed to determine which pieces will or won’t be fractured when fracture ratio is lower than 1.
Do not further partition pieces into groups by connectivity.

Enabling this option will further divide the pieces into separate, connected groups of geometry. Normally each input cell point will create one output piece. However, with concave objects this can mean that disconnected pieces of geometry are placed in the same piece. This option allows the piece numbers to be overwritten by this operation, which is fast and acceptable if you don’t need the piece numbers to match the input point numbers.
Scatter points based on the fog volume generated.

Scatter points based on the specified point attribute in the incoming geometry.
        For example, the
can be used to paint a
The name of the point attribute to use as a density attribute when scattering points.
The number of points to scatter.
Do not affect the number of scattered points.
Multiply the number of scattered points by the piece’s volume.
Large pieces can generate a lot more points.  Use the
option for better control over the total number of points being generated.
Multiply the number of scattered points by the piece’s bounding box’s maximum axis length.
Multiply the number of scattered points by the average value across the piece of the given attribute.

Enable fitting the range of the piece’s volume or max axis length value to a min and max range.
    Values outside the input range will be clamped to the input range.
Specify the input value’s minimum and maximum range.
Specify the output value’s minimums and maximum range.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
The random seed for scattering points.
Use additional Voronoi cell points from the fourth input.
If a name attribute exists on the points, only points with a matching name will be used for the piece being fractured. Wildcards are supported.
Specifies a group of points from the fourth input geometry to use for Voronoi cells.
The type of noise. Select from

The resolution of the fog volume.
    The higher the resolution, the slower the fracturing time will be.
    Smaller geometry will require higher volume resolution.
The frequency of the noise. Higher values give smaller scaled details in the noise.

The offset of the input into the noise function. If you visualize the noise as a 2D graph or 3D height field, this has the effect of "panning" across the space of possible noise outputs. If you have the general noise effect you want but just want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
The low density level to cutoff at. Density below this value will be discarded.
Break off corners of pieces to create chips.
The overall ratio out of all the pieces to perform chipping.
The overall seed for the ratio of fracturing.
Randomizes the chipping ratio for each piece by this amount, when fracturing per piece.
The ratio of corner points to use to generate chipping cutting planes.
A normalized distance from corner to the center of the piece where the chipping plane will be instantiated.
Amount of noise to add to the corner normal to align the cutting plane to.

Convert geometry back to N-gons after applying boolean.
    Turning this off can sometime make the result more stable.
The size of the polygons added for the edge and interior detail.
Use Boolean to obtain edge detail.
The size of the noise pattern. Higher values give larger scaled details in the noise.
An increment for the noise element size between fracture iterations.
This parameter has no effect on the first fracture iteration.
An increment for the noise height between fracture iterations.
This parameter has no effect on the first fracture iteration.

Convert geometry back to N-gons after applying boolean.
    Turning this off can sometime make the result more stable.
Add noise to the interior points, scaled based on their distance to the surface.
The size in world space of the voxels in the SDF used for depth sampling.
The type of noise added to the interior points.
The frequency of the noise. Higher values give smaller scaled details in the noise.

The offset of the input into the noise function. If you visualize the noise as a 2D graph or 3D height field, this has the effect of "panning" across the space of possible noise outputs. If you have the general noise effect you want but just want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
Use the default voronoi fractured geometry.
Perform a convex decomposition from the fractured input geometry.
Use packed sphere primitives from the fractured input geometry.

The maximum distance from a point on the geometry to it’s closest convex hull edge.
    Reducing this value will produce convex hulls that are a closer fit to the input geometry, but the geometry may be split into more segments.

The size of voxels in the output VDB volume.
    Surface features smaller than this will not be in the output VDB.
Determines the smallest sphere size in voxel units.
Determines the largest sphere size in voxel units.
No more than this number of spheres are generated per VDB primitive.

Apply constraint properties to the output constraint geometry.
    The
can be used for advanced constraint setups.
of the constraint data (for example, the
) to use in the DOP network.
The starting strength of the glue bonds of primary fracture.
The number to multiply the primary strength with for each increment of fracture level.
The strength of glue bonds of corner chips.
Randomly varies the strength of each glue bond.
Specifies a different constraint type to switch to if the glue constraint is broken by the
Switch to Soft Constraint when Broken
of the constraint data (for example, the
) to use in the DOP network.

Specifies whether the constraint affects position, orientation, or both.
    This does not apply to glue constraints, which work by simulating glued chunks together as a single object with a compound collision shape.
Specifies the strength of the force that attempts to match the transforms of the two anchors.
This value is equivalent to the frequency of a spring.

Specifies how much damping is applied to the motion.
    A value of 0 specifies no damping, and a value of 1 provides just enough damping to prevent oscillation.
    Values between 0 and 1 allow oscillation (with some damping), and values greater than 1 provide increasingly damped motion that has no oscillation.
This value is equivalent to the damping ratio of a spring.
The group that is currently being fractured will be highlighted.
Display the noise used for determining the discontinuity for concentric cracks.
Display the magnitude distribution of the edge noise.
Use randomly scattered points on the surface as impact points.
Do not affect the number of scattered points.
Multiply the number of scattered points by the average value across the piece of the given attribute.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
Use points from the fourth input as additional impact points.
If a name attribute exists on the points, only points with a matching name will be used for the piece being fractured. Wildcards are supported.
The group of points from the fourth input to use as impact points.
The number of radial cracks to generate for each impact point.
Do not affect the number of radial cracks.
Multiply the number of radial cracks by the average value across the piece of the given attribute.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
The variance in the number of radial cracks for each piece.
The seed for the variance of the number of radial cracks.
The fracture ID for this fracture. The output attributes and groups associated with this fracture will have this tag.
The minimum width between each concentric crack going outward radially.
Do not affect the minimum width.
Multiply the minimum with by the average value across the piece of the given attribute.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
How far from the origin(s) the concentric cracks spread.
The frequency of the discontinuity noise for concentric cracks.
The amplitude of the discontinuity noise for concentric cracks.
The fracture ID for this fracture. The output attributes and groups associated with this fracture will have this tag.
Break off corners of pieces to create chips.
The overall ratio out of all the pieces to perform chipping.
The overall seed for the ratio of fracturing.
Randomizes the chipping ratio for each piece by this amount, when fracturing per piece,
The ratio of corner points to use to generate chipping cutting planes.
A normalized distance from corner to the center of the piece where the chipping plane will be instantiated.
Amount of noise to add to the corner normal to align the cutting plane to.

Convert geometry back to N-gons after applying boolean.
    Turning this off can sometime make the result more stable.
The size of the polygons to add for the edge noise.
How far to fade off the edge noising from the fracture origins.
How far to fade off the edge noising from the borders of the glass.

The maximum distance from a point on the geometry to it’s closest convex hull edge.
    Reducing this value will produce convex hulls that are a closer fit to the input geometry, but the geometry may be split into more segments.
The strength of the glue bonds between radial cracks.
The strength of the glue bonds between concentric cracks.
The strength of the glue bonds for corner chips.
The group that is currently being fractured will be highlighted.
Display the cutting planes for the grains.
Display the cutting planes for the cuts.
Display the cutting planes for the splinters.
Determine the direction automatically based on the oriented bounding box.
Use the vector specified as the direction of fracturing.
Divide the spacing by the average value across the piece of the given attribute. A smaller value will result in larger spacing.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
The size of offset randomly applied to each grain line.
The seed of the random offset.
Distance between peaks of lowest frequency noise.
The size of polygons used to cut the grain lines.
The fracture ID for this fracture. The output attributes and groups associated with this fracture will have this tag.
Rotates the cutting plane along the axis perpendicular to the grain cut direction, when
Divide the spacing by the average value across the piece of the given attribute. A smaller value will result in larger spacing.
The name of the primitive or point float attribute to use as multiplier. The average value across the piece being fractured will be used.
The size of offset randomly applied to each cut.
The seed of the random offset.
The amount of splinters for each cut.
The fracture ID for this fracture. The output attributes and groups associated with this fracture will have this tag.
Create proxy geometry from the high-resolution pieces using a

The maximum distance from a point on the geometry to it’s closest convex hull edge.
    Reducing this value will produce convex hulls that are a closer fit to the input geometry, but the geometry may be split into more segments.
Specifies how to apply the clustering to the input geometry.

primitive attribute to combine pieces into clusters.
        This will result in fewer objects in the simulation.
        The constraint geometry is also updated to reflect the new pieces.

The input geometry is not modified, but primitive groups are added to the constraint geometry to identify constraints between clusters, internal constraints in a cluster, etc.
        This can be used with the

to, for example, create stronger constraints between pieces in the same cluster.
        With this approach, the clustered chunks may be broken apart during the simulation by breaking the constraints within a cluster.
The offset of the cellular noise added to the input points.
The jitter of the cellular noise added to the input points.

The size of the cells for the noise added to the input points.
    This roughly corresponds to the size of the clusters.
The probability that a particular piece will be detached.
The random seed used for detachment.
The strength of glue bonds between grains.
The strength of glue bonds between cuts and splinters.
The group that is currently being fractured will be highlighted.
Display the volume distribution used for scattering.
Display the cutting geometry used to generate the edge detail.
Whether to treat this geometry like the boundary of a solid object, or as a flat surface with no interior or exterior.
Internally, this node converts the input geometry to triangles. This controls whether to convert the triangulated geometry back to N-gons matching the originals for output.
Merge neighboring triangles originating from the same input polygon back together.
If an input polygon is cut as part of the operation, keep it as triangles. Otherwise put triangulated polygons back together.
Use scattered cutting geometry for fracturing.

Uses a grid to perform cuts.
Uses a polygon sphere to perform cuts.

title: RBD Material Fracture
summary: Fractures the input geometry based on a material type.
